abstract.text: Use a document browser to provide access to the user’s text files.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The Document Browser sample code uses a
as the app’s root view controller. The browser defines the structure of the app, and the app displays the browser view when it launches. Users can then use the browser to:
Browse all the text files on the user’s device, in their iCloud drive, or in any supported third-party file providers.
Create new text files.
Open text files.

When the user opens a file, the app transitions to an editor view. There, the user can edit and save the text file. When they are done editing, the app returns to the browser, letting the user open or create another file.

This sample code project demonstrates all the required steps to set up the document browser, to work with the user’s files, and to enable system animations. The following sections describe these steps in more detail.
The Document Browser app performs the following setup and configuration steps:
Assigns a
subclass as the window’s
Specifies the supported document types.
Customizes the document browser’s behavior.
Document browser-based apps must assign a
instance as the app’s
, ensuring that the browser remains in memory throughout the app’s lifetime.
The sample code defines a
subclass named
. It then marks the subclass as the app’s initial view controller in the
storyboard, and  displays the browser view when launched.

All document browser-based apps must also declare the document types that they can open. The sample code app declares support for text files in the project editor’s Info pane. For more information on setting the document type, see
Finally, the sample code configures the document browser in the
class’s

method. Specifically, it enables document creation, and disables multiple document selection. This lets users create new documents from the browser, while also preventing them from opening more than one document at a time.
For more information on configuring a document browser, see
When the user creates a new document, the system calls the document browser delegate’s
method.

code: os_log("==> Creating A New Document.", log: .default, type: .debug)
// Create a new document in a temporary location.
// Make sure the document saved successfully.
os_log("*** Unable to create a new document. ***", log: .default, type: .error)
// Make sure the document closed successfully.
os_log("*** Unable to create a new document. ***", log: .default, type: .error)
// Pass the document's temporary URL to the import handler.

inlineContent.text: In this method, the app creates, saves, and then closes a new text document. If successful, the app passes the URL to the method’s import handler, requesting that the system move the document to its final location. Otherwise, it passes
to the import handler, canceling document creation.
Users can open documents in multiple ways. The sample code handles the following situations:
If the app imports a document (including successfully creating a new document), the system calls the
method.
If the user selects a document from the browser, the system calls the
method.
If the user shares a document with the app, or drags a document into the app, the system calls the app delegate’s
method.
In the first two cases, the app calls the custom
method. In the third case, the app calls the browser’s
method to import the document (if needed). It then calls the
method.
The
method instantiates a
, sets up the document’s animation, opens the document, and then presents the view controller by calling the browser’s
method.
The document browser provides two built-in animations: one for loading a file, another for transitioning to and from the document view.
To enable either of the system-provided document browser animations, first you need to request a transition controller for the document by calling the
method.
To enable the loading animation, assign a
object to the transition controller when you begin to load the document.
Increment the progress as the document loads, making sure to mark it as complete as soon as loading finishes. To simulate slow, incremental loading in the sample code project, uncomment the
class’s
method.

abstract.text: An object that conveys ongoing progress to the user for a specified task.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
Asks the delegate to open a resource specified by a URL, and provides a dictionary of launch options.
A view controller for browsing and performing actions on documents that you store locally and in the cloud.
Reveals, and optionally imports, the document at the provided URL.
Creates a transition controller that provides the standard system-loading and segue animations for the document browser.
Tells the delegate that a document has been successfully imported.
Tells the delegate that the user has selected one or more documents.
Asks the delegate to create a new document.
A view controller that previews, opens, or prints files with a file format that your app can’t handle directly.
A view controller that provides access to documents or destinations outside your app’s sandbox.
A view controller that manages and presents a document stored locally or in the cloud.
Presents a view controller modally.
The root view controller for the window.
Give users access to their local or remote documents from within your app.

abstract.text: Customize the document browser’s look and behavior.

Add a document browser view controller to your app.

abstract.text: Manage your interface using view controllers and facilitate navigation around your app’s content.
